body: Fixed in #462
@jai1 This is unrelated with #462. It happens with Java as well. It's just on the rate out side.

> Please take a look at #436. I think we should use the same trick on the client side. 

Actually at zookeeper-server side, request itself contains [creation-time](https://github.com/apache/zookeeper/blob/master/src/java/main/org/apache/zookeeper/server/FinalRequestProcessor.java#L89) and we can measure latency based on difference of creation-time and current time.
However, at Zookeeper-client, request doesn’t store creation time so, client has to somehow inject creation time (may be value of “ctx” when we issue zk-command) and with aspectj we can intercept [zk-response: ClientCnxn.procesEvent()](https://github.com/apache/zookeeper/blob/master/src/java/main/org/apache/zookeeper/ClientCnxn.java#L519) which has operationType and ctx=creationTime, and can measure the latency. However, we still have to make changes at broker side to make sure we pass creation-time as a “ctx” to measure the latency. Do you think that would be a better solution to measure latency at zk-client?
We should state the version of python, which is 2 or 3, in the document, shouldn't we ?

@yush1ga Good point. I have just tried with python-2.7. It would be great to test it with python-3, but I don't find any Linux distribution that comes with `libboost-pyhton` for python 3 yet. I'll update the doc with the version info.

Let me share the additional investigation for the problem in same environment after @hrsakai .

I checked thread dump about "pulsar-web-\*" when the problem occurred because our additional log stopped [here](https://github.com/yahoo/pulsar/blob/v1.17.2/pulsar-client/src/main/java/com/yahoo/pulsar/client/impl/BinaryProtoLookupService.java#L134) on "pulsar-web-*" thread.
All of "pulsar-web-\*" threads are waiting `CompletableFuture.get()`  to close or create producer.

```
"pulsar-web-46-17" #111 prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f2f0418e000 nid=0x493d waiting on condition [0x00007f2eda555000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: WAITING (parking)
        at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
        - parking to wait for  <0x00000000f47e4650> (a java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$Signaller)
        at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:175)
        at java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$Signaller.block(CompletableFuture.java:1693)
        at java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool.managedBlock(ForkJoinPool.java:3323)
        at java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.waitingGet(CompletableFuture.java:1729)
        at java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.get(CompletableFuture.java:1895)
        at com.yahoo.pulsar.client.impl.ProducerBase.close(ProducerBase.java:73)

        at org.eclipse.jetty.websocket.common.io.IOState.notifyStateListeners(IOState.java:184)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.websocket.common.io.IOState.onReadFailure(IOState.java:498)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.websocket.common.io.AbstractWebSocketConnection.readParse(AbstractWebSocketConnection.java:666)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.websocket.common.io.AbstractWebSocketConnection.onFillable(AbstractWebSocketConnection.java:511)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.io.AbstractConnection$ReadCallback.succeeded(AbstractConnection.java:273)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.io.FillInterest.fillable(FillInterest.java:95)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.io.SelectChannelEndPoint$2.run(SelectChannelEndPoint.java:93)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.ExecuteProduceConsume.executeProduceConsume(ExecuteProduceConsume.java:303)
        at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.ExecuteProduceConsume.produceConsume(ExecuteProduceConsume.java:148)

        at io.netty.util.concurrent.DefaultThreadFactory$DefaultRunnableDecorator.run(DefaultThreadFactory.java:144)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)

"pulsar-web-46-16" #109 prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f2f042c4000 nid=0x490f waiting on condition [0x00007f2eda757000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: WAITING (parking)
        at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
        - parking to wait for  <0x00000000f4735e30> (a java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$Signaller)
        at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:175)
        at java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$Signaller.block(CompletableFuture.java:1693)

        at com.yahoo.pulsar.client.impl.PulsarClientImpl.createProducer(PulsarClientImpl.java:130)
        at com.yahoo.pulsar.websocket.ProducerHandler.onWebSocketConnect(ProducerHandler.java:74)

        at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.ExecuteProduceConsume.run(ExecuteProduceConsume.java:136)

        at io.netty.util.concurrent.DefaultThreadFactory$DefaultRunnableDecorator.run(DefaultThreadFactory.java:144)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
```

To avoid it, I added 
```
protected final static ExecutorService executors = Executors.newScheduledThreadPool(1,
            new DefaultThreadFactory("pulsar-websocket"));
```
to AbstractWebSocketHandler and made all of `onWebSocket*` methods in `executors.execute(()->{})` block.
Then, WebSocket proxy got to reply correctly.
However, I think it is not best practice at all.

If you have some great ideas, please tell us.
@saandrews any update on this one? Should we move to 1.19?
should we consider it for 1.18?
@merlimat : In many cases it requires to get zk-latency at zk-client side. As per my previous comment do you think we should take aspectJ approach or we can keep this approach?

My main concern is that this is a kind of a wack-a-mole to find all the ZK client library usages. Also, this is not accounting for the ZK requests made by BK client.

That's way I'd prefer to have some automated approach to monitor all the calls. 

Another option could be to use the `ZooKeeperClient` from BookKeeper  master (https://github.com/apache/bookkeeper/blob/master/bookkeeper-server/src/main/java/org/apache/bookkeeper/zookeeper/ZooKeeperClient.java ). This one is collecting metrics on all the ZK calls. You need to instantiate that instead of the regular `ZooKeeper` class.

Sorry for the confusion 

I think I found the issue 
https://github.com/yahoo/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/com/yahoo/pulsar/broker/service/Consumer.java

Need to change 
                msgOut.recordEvent(metadataAndPayload.readableBytes());
To
                msgOut.recordMultipleEvents(metadataAndPayload.getNumMessagesInBatch(), metadataAndPayload.readableBytes());

What is the main intent of having the configuration switch to enable/disable persistent/non-persistent topics on a broker? Is is to protect the brokers while the non-persistent mode is being tested out and reaches maturity? 

Couldn't this be also achieved with isolation policies?

@saandrews sure, but let's try to get this in soon. This is reducing the ZK metadata footprint considerably. Also this gives freedom to update the metadata format without worrying about backward compatibility issues.
Closing this old issue for now. Feel free to re-open if you think there is still need for this change.

> Is it to protect the brokers while the non-persistent mode is being tested out and reaches maturity?

yes, it helps us to start using this feature and we can use this switch to avoid impact of unknown issues for persistent topics until this feature is matured.

> Couldn't this be also achieved with isolation policies?

yes, it can be achieved but based on team discussion if broker starts with only non-persistent mode then admin doesn't have to run behind for even non-persistent namespace and load-manager automatically takes care assignment of bundles.

> yes, it can be achieved but based on team discussion if broker starts with only non-persistent mode then admin doesn't have to run behind for even non-persistent namespace and load-manager automatically takes care assignment of bundles.

Sounds good. Is the plan to keep the switch temporarely or indefinitely?

Also, as discussed in the mailing list, can you start drafting a wiki page to recollect all the design points to support non persistent topics?

> Also, as discussed in the mailing list, can you start drafting a wiki page to recollect all the design points to support non persistent topics?

Sure, I will draft it based on design agreement we had on #438 #452  and this PR.

> Is the plan to keep the switch temporarely or indefinitely?

I think we can remove it once this feature gets matured and broker can handle non-persistent topic tradeoff which won't impact ongoing persistent topic performance.

By specifying `<redirectTestOutputToFile>true</redirectTestOutputToFile>`, maven sends the test output to individual files in `target/surefire-reports`. In travis we cannot see that anyway, but in Jenkins (when we switch) or in local tests, you can see the logs.

I will close this and re-send PR.

yes, right now, client considers uncompressed message size while sending message to broker and I don't see any clear reason why can't we consider compressed-message size instead, because broker stores compressed data only to to BK which will be < 5MB only. So, I think we can add validation after compressing the payload.
@merlimat do you see any issue for considering compressed size while sending msg to broker.

My only concern is that it might be tricky to know upfront whether the message would be accepted or rejected (If you send msg >5MB). 

One other thing we could do is to make the Max to be configurable, since the 5MB was very arbitrary anyway.

If you can configure it on broker and client, you can raise and be 100% sure it gets accepted, even though compression didn't reduce the size for a particular message.

> One other thing we could do is to make the Max to be configurable, since the 5MB was very arbitrary anyway.

If it's configurable then client may start sending msg with unreasonable size which will be rejected at broker due to  [frame-size/storage-limitation](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-common/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/common/api/PulsarDecoder.java#L60), So, client will not know up-front.

> If you can configure it on broker and client, you can raise and be 100% sure it gets accepted

If it's configurable at client then value might be different than what broker is allowing and it requires some type of sync when client connects to broker.? Also, it may not address payload which can be highly compressible (eg.xml,json)

> If it's configurable then client may start sending msg with unreasonable size which will be rejected at broker due to frame-size/storage-limitation, So, client will not know up-front.

Max-frame size could be negotiated between client and broker in Connect/Connected handshake
@merlimat Why can't we check size post-compression?

I am not saying we cant, just trying to scope all the implications :)

If you check the size after compression you're not sure whether a particular message will go through or not.

Example:
I have a 6MB JSON document. Most probably it will compress to 600KB, but I cannot tell 100%. If the JSON is weird enough it might be 5.5MB. 

So if I send this 6MB message it might get rejected by the client.

Typically the safe-size buffer for compression is _bigger_ that the uncompressed content, to account for incompressible content plus the compressor overhead.

In my view, compressing is an optimization to safe network/IO/disk space, but the max size should be enforced irrespectively of that. So if you have 6MB or 10MB entries, you should be able to configure the system to handle that, with 100% assurance that it will processed correctly, instead of relying on the assumption that compression will solve it, which might be true in 99.99% of the cases but fail at unexpected times.

If there needs to be a hard limit (for 100% assurance), the application can enforce that itself without any changes in the system (Pulsar).

My perspective is from what I think as the origin of this ask:   If there is a system(Pulsar)  limit, and if the system can honor a "violating" request by optimizing the request, it should.  Agreed that sometimes the system will not always succeed in this, but it should try.  That could reduce user impact by reducing the number of violations, and some use-cases might prefer that.

> If there is a system(Pulsar) limit, and if the system can honor a "violating" request by optimizing the request, it should. 

Ok, I agree with that. The configurable max message size could be a separate from this, though something that on its own we should do at some point.

> The configurable max message size could be a separate from this

I will create a separate issue to provide a way to configure this size and will create a separate PR for both of them.
Isn't Bookkeeper max entry size 5mb?

@merlimat :
[Yahoo-BK](https://github.com/yahoo/bookkeeper/blob/yahoo-4.3/bookkeeper-server/src/main/java/org/apache/bookkeeper/proto/PerChannelBookieClient.java#L113) allows maxFrameSize = 5MB so, I think there is no need to make max-length configurable for now.?
